description.text: translucent purple

My wife asked me to make a couple of plastic parts to hold her razor & body wash upside down on out shower caddy. I did this a few months back, but changed the design recently to make it stay in place better.
I printed these with PLA at 20% infill. Each one took 34 minutes to print.

title: Sandpaper handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I was wet sanding a mode and I got tired of my finger getting wet and numb. I made this to hold my sand paper in an ergonomic handle. Has a flat side for flat services and a round side for working around curved edges.

I printed mine vertically with 20% infill. Its really strong, so no worries!
Made this in Sketchup. Slide the sandpaper into to the top of the tool. Any extra hanging out can be rolled onto the handle after the paper has lost some of its grit due to use.

title: Morphi snap cube inspired by @Mathgrrl Laura Taalman's poly-snaps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by @mathgirrl's Poly-Snaps http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:208591, we designed a quick snap cube from scratch in Morphi using cubes in the shape pack. https://www.morphiapp.com Print 6 pieces + assemble the cube! Try making it multi-color. :)

This is part of our Maker Education series where people of all ages and skill levels can learn about the basics of 3D modeling/design, printing and more. We will be releasing K-12 lesson plans for this model shortly. Stay tuned!

In Morphi, users of all skill levels can make 3D printable objects on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. www.morphiapp.com Download the app for free for iPad and IPad mini on the App Store (with in app purchases for enhanced features). https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8

Schools and other institutions purchasing apps for 20+ devices may purchase Morphi at a discount thru our new Morphi Edu app which participates in Apple's Volume Purchasing Program (VPP). https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi-edu/id1003747185?mt=8

Coming soon for Android, Mac and other platforms! Copyright 2012-2015, The Inventery, Inc.

We're inspired by Makerbot's Laura Taalman @mathgrrl and her body of work on Thingiverse. We looked at her poly-snap design on Thingiverse http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:208591and wanted to see if we could recreate it from scratch in Morphi using cubes in the shapes pack. Print 6 pieces (preferably in more than one color) + assemble the cube. We can't wait to try designing more of her polyhedra. Stay tuned!

description.text: 14mm negative (standard airsoft threading) tantal-style flashhider. Made and designed by me

It is adjustable pasta cutter. It can make different size of noodle or pasta, and only change you need to do is changing the spacer size.

I printed mine at 0.1mm resolution, 80% filling, 3 layers wall/bottom/top, G-code was generated by Cura Engine. Tested, works well enough.

It includes

  1. blade: 1mm thick blade, with reinforcement in the middle.
  2. two pieces of shaft : I need 10cm shaft, however not sure about the print will stick to bed well enough for a tall and skinny part, I decided to cut to half length to 5cm each.
  3. handle: basically hollow inside with beam support inside.
  4. handle cap: fit at the end of handle to close the hollow.
    5 spacer: I had the choice to combine blade and spacer. However, I may want different thickness of my noodle. With spacer, I only need to print another set of spacer, instead of changing all the blades.

Enjoy it~!

title: Samsung Galaxy Note 5 Dock with Sound Horns

description.text:
03/06/2016 - I uploaded a new STL file, Note5Dock2.slt. I removed the front lip and move the side tabs back. This makes accessing the buttons easier.

It is a single piece that allows you to mount the original USB plug. There are two sound horns (yes, I know there is only one speaker on the bottom but it looks better symmetrical and the other horn can route sounds to the mic) to allow you to hear the sounds without being too muffled or distorted.

There are mounting holes and guides on the bottom to align and mount the optional pad with.

If you are looking for a dock for a Note 3, check my other version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952461.

Printing the unit is pretty straight forward. To mount the power cord, I attached it to the phone and put the phone in the dock. Once it was where I wanted it, I used hot glue to mount it in place. I routed the cord out the bottom and hot glued it down. There is an optional bottom pad that can be printed in a flex type material to serve as a non-slip bottom. Or you can print in a hard plastic and use to trap the cord in the grove. Rubber feet can be put onto the hard plastic pad then.

For nice, sharp prints, you can't beat a blower (rather than a fan) with a duct focusing the air right on the nozzle. This version uses a 50mm x 15mm blower to replace the fan that blows on the part and includes brackets for attaching to the existing fan that blows on the extruder.

This spring thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:687668) makes an excellent object for testing your new setup.

Print with 0.2mm layers and 0.4mm line width. Remove the existing fan and mount this to the extruder fan with the same M3 nuts and bolts. You'll also need a 1" 6-32 (or 25mm M3) bolt and nut to mount the blower to the brackets. Just superglue the duct onto the output port of the blower.

comments.text: 30mm or 40mm fan for extruder???
comments.author: RaOno

comments.text: The description specifies a 50mm x 15mm blower.  These are pretty commonly available and give you plenty of air.
comments.author: RaOno

comments.text: AWESOME! i accidentally bought the larger fan blower on amazon because i want paying attention. now i can actually put them to use.
comments.author: CreamyMemes

comments.text: did you attach the blower to the same power supply as the original fan?  are there any difficulties?
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text: I used a 24v blower - same as the original fan - and just plugged it into the same connector as the original fan.  It works with no problems.
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text: where did you order/get the small blower from?
comments.author: Kcobbler

comments.text: I ordered this one: http://www.ebay.com/itm/331185700350 from e-bay. It is a 24v blower for the newer M2 24v power supply. However, I think the dimensions are relatively standard and you could probably get a compatible one from Digikey or Mouser as well.
comments.author: Kcobbler

description.text:
Cannot generate correct gcode for this stl file with sf35.
I tried different settings but there is always a problem, either with an incomplete layer or printing in the air. These problems are reproducible: you can see that the gcode is wrong when using a tool such as Pleasant3D.
When I accidentally made the hole in the object too large (first attempt) there was no problem. When I lay the object flat on the base for printing (rotate in repG) there is no problem but the object then lacks strenght.
When I remove the hole (in Sketchup) and print the object without hole there is no problem either...

Try generating gcode that works for this, then print on Makerbot ToM or other 3D printer.
Update: rotate the object 180 degrees (around z-axis) and then it prints fine. Clearly a bug in skeinforge as this rotation should have no influence.

description.text:
Another part to the upcoming generator. A mashup of classic principles with a patented (thisismacbailey) nouveau approach.

This is exemplary of what things I expect to see developed by fellow designers ..
1) parts that can't be readily produced by conventional means,
2) precision considerations,
3) interconnectivity of multiple parts and working parts,
4) upgrades of classic ideas.

Raising the bar has never been more exhilarating!

Just watch ..

Keeping up readership!
Questions/comments appreciated ..

This is a prototype bearing. I wanted to make a bearing that works right off the build plate, and that wont open to allow the ball bearings to fall out.

The small tabs were added to allow me to have lots of grip. I figured it would take a little torque to break the ball bearings free.

I printed it but the tolerances were to tight. The balls stuck on the inside. I did get the bearing to spin but its not smooth due to a few broken balls.

If its scaled up I think the gaps would grow and the balls may easily break free with out damage.

description.text:
This is the second bearing I have made. I learned a lot from my first one. before designing the bearing I printed a test plate with many gaps of descending size. I found the 1/64 inch is as close as the printer can put two surfaces without them touching on the X and Y axis.

The gap between the roller and the case is 1/64 on each side for a total of 1/32 play on the X and Y axis.

The rollers spin decently but I need to add a spacer plate to the rollers so they don't touch, or change the roller diameter. And make the gaps 1/80 so that the PLA just barely bonds, and a tiny bit of torque will break it free.(Prototype Bearing 3)

The bearing does work well.

title: Kossel 2020 tower braces for Folgertech and similar designs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Greatly reduces the dreaded "tower shake" when doing honeycomb and some other infill at high speeds. Noticeably improves the rigidity of the Kossel 2020 design. Also, this is a good upgrade if you are transporting your Kossel a lot. It will help ensure that the extrusions don't slip if the machine gets jarred.

I tried smaller braces that fit up tight against the vertex brackets, and they seemed to do almost nothing. These actually work.

I noticed an definite improvement in the surface quality of my printed parts after I installed these.

Created in DesignSpark Mechanical.

The carbon fiber box tubing can be purchased from HobbyKing.

300mm length:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__55336__Carbon_Fiber_Square_Tube_10_x_10_x_300mm_US_Warehouse_.html

250mm length:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__55335__Carbon_Fiber_Square_Tube_10_x_10_x_250mm_US_Warehouse_.html

The 250mm length is adequate if you are using 300mm horizontal extrusions. My Kossel uses 350mm horizontals and I had to go with the 300mm box tubing. You must accurately determine the proper length of the CF tubing before final assembly. Do a trial fit of the parts and tubing in order to determine that length. The upper ends should almost meet when the are the correct length. (see transparent view of center brace to get an idea of how close they should be)

Use 16mm long M3 capscrews to secure the box tuning into the braces. Make sure they are bottomed out. Mark with masking tape before final assembly if your tubes are tight and your are not sure if they are bottoming.

The braces attach to the extrusions with 8mm M3 capscrews and T-nuts.

I suggest printing in ABS for flexibility. It makes assembly easier. There should be adequate clearance between the corner braces and the capscrews securing your ball joint rods to your carriages (unless you are using a weird carriage that is wider than usual)

The tolerances are fairly tight to match my printer. I suggest printing out one set first and testing the fit of the CF box tubing. Scale up the part by 0.5% or so if you really need to. It all goes together quite easily if you do things in the right order. If you need help, leave a comment.

No chopping, hacking, or butchering with netfab or meshmixer, etc please. If you want something changed, please ask. Thank you.

title: Phial of Salts prop - Bioshock Infinite
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a prop of the Salts bottle from Bioshock Infinite. There are files for both a static and a hero light-up version! For a static version print one each of:
bioshock_salts_neck_plug_static.stl
bioshock_salts_stopper_static.stl
bioshock_salts_neck_ring.stl
bioshock_salts_bottle_final.stl For a light-up version print one each of:
bioshock_salts_neck_for_glowstick.stl
bioshock_salts_stopper_for_glowstick.stl (print in shell mode)
bioshock_salts_neck_ring.stl
bioshock_salts_bottle_final.stl The example above was printed on an Afinia H479. The solid models were created in a trial of Alibre Design and the label was made in GIMP by tracing game screenshots. BTW, if there's something wrong with those files let me know... They are slightly different from the ones I printed as they were rotated in netfabb and re-exported before uploading (originally I set the orientation in my printer software).

In addition, you will need these supplies:
-Clear ABS filament
-Clear blue paint (Tamiya PS-39 spray can or X-23 w/airbrush)
-Tan spray paint (such as Krylon gloss Almond)
-Red chisel tip acrylic paint marker
-Black fine tip acrylic or oil-based paint marker
-Sharpie marker
-Tan printer paper
-Krylon matte clear finish
-Chrome tape or chrome Monokote
-Spray adhesive or Xyron sticker maker
-Plastic welder (like Ambroid or Bondene)
-LED Glow stick, blue (Target camping department) (light-up version only) Tools:
-Hobby knife
-Sandpaper
-Dremel w/ sanding drum & cutting disc
-Scissors
-Acetone vapor smoothing apparatus (optional) Procedure: 1) Print all parts. At least the bottle and stopper should be made from clear ABS filament. You won't ever get a glass-clear print from this stuff, but what you do get is a diffused/translucent look that is perfect for this prop. The striations left by the print process break up and help distribute the light more evenly. Also, if your printer generates support material inside the bottle, don't remove it - it further helps with diffusing the LED cone. 2) (Optional but recommended) Smooth all parts with an acetone vapor bath (I use a variation of the method here: http://solidoodletips.wordpress.com/2012/11/10/presto-part-finisher/ ). It gives the printed parts a glossy and glass-smooth finish. Again, this step is not absolutely necessary but it really improves the look and feel of the prop. 3)(a) (Light-up version only) Using the Dremel with sanding drum, remove the ridges and the loop on the grip of the LED glowstick as shown in the photos above. Don't take too much off- stop and check often to make sure that the diameter is just small enough for an interference fit inside of the stopper. 3)(b) Cut most of the LED light stick's clear tube off- you'll only need to leave about 3/8" to 1/2" sticking out of the grip portion. Also make a small notch in the stopper as shown in the photos above. The screw on the LED light stick grip will slot in here. This not only disguises the screw, but also serves to lock the handle in place within the stopper. 4) Paint the stopper (& bottle for a static version) and neck ring. Tamiya PS-39 is a little expensive but if you're careful with application it gives GREAT results on the 3d print ABS. Next make a paper stencil (see photo above) or freehand trace an outline of the stopper detail with a fine sharpie. Use a med-large chisel tip acrylic paint pen to fill in the red. Once that's dry, use a fine point black paint pen for the outline. Finally, paint the portion of the glow stick grip that is visible between the stopper and neck ring with clear blue. 5)(a) Label time. Print two labels from the .PNG file above (they should be 2.4" wide/tall). It's best to print the labels on tan paper to match the game texture. You may choose to weather this a bit (hint: tea or coffee) but I did not. Apply a matte clear spray coat to protect the printing. Run the side of a sharpie tip along the cut edge of the label to black it out. 5)(b) (Light-up only) In the game, the glow of the salts does not transmit through the labels on the bottle. Chrome tape or silver monokote (check the airplane section of the hobby shop) will stop light bleed by reflecting it back inside the bottle. 5)(c) Use a Xyron sticker maker, permanent double stick tape, or spray adhesives to apply adhesive to the back of the labels. Apply labels to bottle. 6) Assembly! Glue the neck plug into the bottle with a plastic welder like Ambroid or Bondene. Don't use acetone- it plays havoc on the glossy surface left by the vapor smoothing and the neck may craze or otherwise deform. (Light-up only) The stump of the LED light stick's clear tube will friction fit into the hole in the neck plug. The neck ring will be trapped between the two- glue is optional for this part. Just twist the stopper to turn the light on! That's it! Please post any questions or things you made :)

remixed_from.title: Extruder for FolgerTech Prusa i3 (v-groove bearing and flat feeder)

description.text:
This is a modification for FolgerTech extruder to include bearing mounts into model. This extruder requires further modification to use original bolts and screws (the mounting hole of the lever needs to be bigger to accommodate the bronze spacer that is in original extruder, and the bolt cap rest needs to be modified for the cylindric cap.
As this extruder didn't work for me (original spring tension is too strong and motor is skipping instead of extruding), I include the OpenScad file I used. You will need the original models to import and work with.
This is minimal changes needed to use the original fixtures. However the lever itself and lever cap can be changed to be less requiring to the printing process (e.g. to eliminate thin walls) as the volume this lever can take is limited merely by "looks good", e.g. you can expand in at least two directions to make it easier to print and easier to assemble.

Even if you don't plan on using them in a game of magic they do add a cool piece to anyone's collection. I haven't yet purchased a MakerBot to print these. I would love to see how these turn out. included are the STLs to each coin and .thing file. Thanks for downloading, happy printing!
~Ipsec

description.text:
All of my filament was stored in the cardboard boxes MatterHackers shipped them in with more spools piled around and on top of those boxes. My supplies and tools were in my desk drawers and a small toolbox. It was a mess in my office and made getting at the filaments to change them a challenge. It was time to do something about it.
This is not really a 3D printable object although I have included a prototype STL file I used to evaluate the design and a prototype drawer pull file that I used to confirm my choice of drawer pull hardware.
The cabinet shown is cherry and cherry ply with full extension slide drawers, custom designed filament drawers, and Craftsman style pulls from Horton Brass. The bottom drawer holds larger supplies such as acetone, a couple of boxes of misprints and stuff, and will also hold my printing plates after I make some dividers. The two small top drawers are for tools and small supplies like filament clips, Wolfbite, nozzles, etc. I need to print some organizers for them as well.
Joinery used Festool dominos for tenons and dovetails for the bottom storage drawer and top storage drawers.

This is a component meant to be joined to another 3D model so that you can insert a nut and mount it on a tripod. You could stick this on one of the many phone cases here on Thingiverse, for example. If you are not comfortable with 3D modelling software you can just use MakerWare to print this so that it's slightly overlapping another object. I tested this process and "designed" a tripod mount version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:76286 in about 2 minutes. It's almost done printing now. This nut adapter is designed with a little clip to stop the nut from falling out.

You should probably print one by itself as a test to make sure everything fits.  I designed it for ABS shrinkage but it shouldn't be too loose in PLA.  
Use 3D modelling software to attach this mesh to another object.  Print with the large rectangular opening up, as it is oriented in the provided files.  Insert a 1/4" - 20 nut all the way in.  
If you are using MakerWare start by adding this nut adapter to the stage along with another model.  Position the adapter by rotating it around the Z axis only and moving it so that it's slightly overlapping the other object.  Both openings of the adapter should be accessible and the amount of overlap should be less than 1.6mm to prevent the other object from intruding into the internal volume of the adapter.  Check to make sure that the adapter does not intrude into important spaces in the other object.  Print.  Insert a 1/4" - 20 nut all the way in.

comments.text: Hi thanks for the compliment for the design. As far as the print settings I used: I printed the Radiant Blossom on my Da Vinci 1.0 at .3 layer height with 1.75 mm ABS filament. I am not too familiar with the slicing program you used. On my Da Vinci the extruder heats up to 212 degrees Celsius. My guess is if you did not want the internal supports to show through technically you could just make the model solid however that may use up more plastic than intended. It's hit or miss with ABS plastic sometimes.

description.text:
This is meant to be a way to track damage in World of Darkness pen-and-paper role playing games. In the World of Darkness, damage comes in three flavors:
  • bashing (marked with a single slash)
  • lethal (marked as an X)
  • aggravated (marked as an asterix)
    • That's all well and good, but in practice, one's character sheet can get a little ragged from all the marking and erasing. Also, gaming is always more fun with dice and counters and markers and the like. So... I made this to give gamers a fun physical way of tracking damage. It also occurred to me while making this that it could be a useful tool for gamers with visual disabilities, since you can feel the different marks. EDIT: I just changed it a bit so that the bottom face is completely flat, as it seems like that would likely print better. I've also added a STL with 9 20mm cubes ready for printing.

1) print out the desired number of cubes (most likely 7 for typical WoD characters)
2) when playing, start out with all the cubes lined up, with one of the blank sides facing up
3) as your character takes damage, turn the die so that the appropriate face is showing (bashing, lethal, or aggravated) I'm also uploading the SCAD file, in case anyone wants a differently sized cube (the STL has 20mm sides). There's also a "shrink" parameter at the top of the file that controls how thick the borders and the lines are.

comments.text: I like the concept! Thinking of modding it already to make it easy to string them together into a health track, and ways to keep the state persistent so you can just "tie up" your health track between sessions. :)

description.text: A pair of die that are easy to roll.

Watertight Vase

By that I mean this part will hold real water and not leak. I have printed several vase-like parts before, and they all leaked when I put water in them. This makes such parts far less useful than if they were water tight.

This part has double walls - not counting the spiral ribs which are really just decoration - and each wall is made with 4 loops. The bottom is also double walled with each surface made with 4 layers.

The second photo shows what a layer height of 0.300 mm looks like. Normally I use 0.200 mm, but I wanted to see if increasing this as a way to reduce total print time would be OK. The final result is not as good as 0.200 mm, but I still think it is acceptable.

I used Craftware to slice the part, after running the original STL file through 3D Builder to correct errors. Total print time for this part was 11 hours 11 minutes.

comments.text: I'm printing this right now.  Will be my largest attempt.   I noticed the 'double wall' causes some rough layers. Maybe it was just the way my Cura settings were.  I think I'd just rather print this all solid and it should come out much better.  (Pics soon. 11hrs for me as well)

title: MakerGear M2 Tool Holder with LCD Mount

description.text:
This is a remix of a fantastic toolholder that I found here on Thingiverse. I added a Full Graphic LCD panel to my printer and I needed a place to mount it. The best location was already taken by my tool holder so I decided that I needed a new version that could do it all. The LCD gets mounted to the pad with Velcro, so it can me removed and used remotely if desired. I also angled the Allen key holders slightly. In the original design they dragged on the back of the filament spool and made a "clicking" noise that I found annoying. The holder has been hollowed out to reduce print time and save plastic.

Updates to r4 (8/23/15):
--Retaining hook on right side made deeper to improve stability
-Square clearance hole added so that it can be used with both versions of the Full-Graphic display (red PCB or white PCB)
-stiffening rib added under shelf to compensate for extra hole
-Chamfers added to tops of holes to ease insertion of tools

A mix of two sources, meant to accommodate more options printing, and some filament effects, as well as pins and / or NFC tags

Hello all, Hopefully this will fit together the way I envisioned.

My suggestion is to print the main body in ether GITD Green or Dark Apple Green.

Print the Enlightened Logo in Transparent Green, and superglue in place.

Emboss your Level onto the level pin, print it in Transparent Yellow, and ink the top in black. Superglue in place.

Emboss your IGN onto the Nameplate, Use Transparent Filament, Ink the top in Green. Superglue in place.

Stick a NFC tag into the hole at the back, programmed with whatever info you wish to have triggered (such as your IngressStats, your local group's webpage, Your Agent's G+ info, etc.), put a couple brass pinstays through the Pin Closure, superglue into place.

Have fun.

title: Parametric Wearable Container with Slip-On Cap

description.text:
This thing started out as a micro cache container for geocaching. It quickly got out of hand and can now be used for anything from a sharpie necklace to a candy jar. You can customize the size, shape, text and even put a loop on this to attach a strap.   
I only had enough time to print out 2 sharpie containers and a small box. The default dimensions will produce a perfect sized sharpie case. The inside and outside container shapes are independently customisable for those of you wishing to use this to house a tool or pen. I was thinking of making one for my exact-o knife. It will give me a bigger and more ergonomic handle. How about a pillbox key chain or maybe even making a glow-light.  How about attaching your pocket watch to your new single cigar carrying case?  
This thing is being listed under household containers but needs its own category for just being awesome!  
One drawback of making such an awesome thing is that the text may not work for all configurations. Low side counts specifically will not work well.

• Fixed Containers so that low wall counts work better
  • Added ability to make 3 sided containers
  • Small fixes in the code

• Fixed bug where sphere would protrude below bottom of container
  • Changed wall width of loop to be indepently controlled

• Customize
  • Print
  • Use!

I've created a car chassis! If you print it as is to scale, it is about 5 inches long, and a little less than that in width. It will work for whatever servos you want, and it was made for standard little motors (whose axles are about 2mm in width). Of course, all parts are made to
accommodate the slight expansion that occurs during printing with a MakerBot Replicator 2X and an unheated bed (since this is what I have access to).

One of the things I have purchased in the past (and are usually not very cheap) and could be effectively printed by my MakerBot (which I am still waiting for my kit) would be molecular model kits.  I quickly made up some common bond configurations and types.  I will probably add some more once I actually have a MakerBot to test the prints.  I kind of eyeballed the tetrahedral atom so print that at your own risk (as with the rest of it).  I am also including the scad files so you can add additional types, change the relative atom sizes (to represent the relative sizes of different elements), bond lengths, and so on.

1) Print the components you want
2) Assemble them and have fun!

title: Hot-end mount for Ormerod for a Chinese E3D replika

description.text:
Hello,

this is a hot-end mount for a cheap Chinese E3D replika for an Ormerod MK1 or MK2. It is suitable only for the old x-carriage. It is not designed for version 546.1 and upwards. It may work but it also may fail to work.

Features:

  • Mounting holes for dc42's proximity sensors (except for the mini version)
  • Enough holes for cable ties
  • Mounting hole for a LED that should not influence the proximity sensor
  • Prepared for a second fan duct holder

At the moment it is untested.

V1.2:

  • Fixed designing issues
  • Completely rework
  • Changed nozzle height
  • Improved cable ties
  • Strongen connection holes for sensor
  • Carriage part is now thicker
  • Some small designing changes

V1.1:

  • Removed cable duct as it is not practicable.
  • Added pocket for the heater block as it was too close at the plastic and I do not want to risk melting
  • Strengthened the LED hole as well as the sensor mounting holes.

author: MakerBlock

description.text:
OK. I have finally got around to sorting this out. I know the original model was full of errors and having it a single file was not ideal, so I have cut it up and run it through all kinds of repairing software. It does look like there might be errors in some of the cuts, so make sure you check before you print.

I have cut it up to fit my Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus, so it the pieces are a pretty good size. Once they are all together, the gun should be about the right size. I have not added the 2 trigger handles, they are basic foam covered bike handles, so they should be easy to find. You will need to carefully drill holes to mount them, but again, not that difficult. I also haven't included the various cables, adding real ones will look better.

Some of the pieces are a little "softer" in their detail, but they are fairly big parts and the detail can always be added back in after printing.

I recommend using 2 part epoxy for putting this together, sorry, there are no keys, so the epoxy will give you time to set the pieces in place.

I hope this makes the Smartgun much more printable, I am intending to print it in the not too distant future, so I will post photos as I go.

Enjoy.

author: Edwin3D

description.text:
A Scotch yoke changes a rotating motion into a linear motion. It is an example of a slotted link mechanism. The rotating wheel with an off-centered mounted peg moves the yoke to the left and right. The displacement depends on the size of the slit in the yoke and the position of the peg on the wheel.

This 3D printable model is mainly to illustrate the workings.
For sure, better designs that include sliding and rotation bearings to minimize play and friction can be thought of.

In the model the yoke can be moved by rotating the wheel by hand. Coupling the wheel directly to a motor or using a gear set would provide a controlled linear motion with a changing speed when approaching the maximum extension.

See e.g.: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotch_yoke

The assembled model includes all parts and could be printed as a whole if the spacings between the moving parts is filled with a removable support.

On my simple da Vinci Jr printer I used the plated parts on half the scale (see file) with a 0.2 mm layer height and assembled the parts afterwards. The pictures show the result. The enclosed files 'y1 ... y4' are the stl files of the different parts.

Also the FreeCAD macro and model are included. Parameters such as the tolerance between the moving parts can be adjusted easily.

author: v12345

title: Spectrum DX-9 Telemetry Monitor Holder for Samsung Tab 7 lite

description.text:
inspired by the holder of the post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384223 I took the idea and reworked this holder for the spectrum transmitter DX 9 and adapted.
As Telemetry Monitor a Samsung Tab coming 7 lite used.
It must be printed with support, the Fill density was at 35%
The antenna Recording Dom must be something filled with foam, so that the holder does not slip down. Alternatively, the antenna mounting points at the back of the antenna
transferred to the recording Dom and so that it can be screwed directly to the transmitter.
The receiving surface for the tab must also be lined to prevent falling out of the tabs. Here the recordings have to be revised for other tabs.

angelehnt an den Halter aus dem Beitrag http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384223 habe ich die Idee aufgenommen und diesen Halter für den Spektrum Sender DX-9 überarbeitet und angepasst.
Als Telemetrie-Monitor kommt ein Samsung Tab 7 lite zum Einsatz.
Es muss mit Support gedruckt werden, die Fill Density war bei 35%
Der Antennenaufnahme-Dom muss etwas mit Schaumstoff gefüllt werden, damit der Halter nicht herunter rutsch. Alternativ lassen sich die Antennen Anschraubpunkte an der Rückseite der Antenne
auf den Aufnahme-Dom übertragen und damit kann er dann direkt mit dem Sender verschraubt werden.
Die Aufnahmefläche für das Tab muss ebenfalls unterfüttert werden, um ein herausfallen des Tabs zu verhindern. Für andere Tabs müssen hier die Aufnahmen überarbeitet werden.

title: Spectrum DX-9 FPV Monitor holder for Boscam RX-LCD5802 Diversity Monitor

description.text:
inspired by the holder of the post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384223 I took the idea and reworked this holder for the spectrum transmitter DX 9 and adapted.
As FPV monitor Boscam RX-LCD5802 Diversity Monitor is used.
It must be printed with support, the Fill density was at 35%
The antenna Recording Dom must be something filled with foam, so that the holder does not slip from the transmitter antenna down. Alternatively, the antenna mounting points at the back of the antenna can be transferred to the receiving dome, so the holder can be screwed directly to the transmitter.
The monitor itself is fastened and fixed by a screw-nut combination.
In addition to the holder these parts are to be printed and is additionally provided with M5 square nuts in the screw nuts. The screw retainer for keeping the receiver is equipped with 2 countersunk screws M5x10.
On diversity receiver receiving the screw housing is slightly loosened and tightened again carefully after insertion of the recording. Thus, the countersunk screws are fixed and do not rotate the screw on the monitor.

angelehnt an den Halter aus dem Beitrag http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384223 habe ich die Idee aufgenommen und diesen Halter für den Spektrum Sender DX-9 überarbeitet und angepasst.
Als FPV-Monitor kommt ein Boscam RX-LCD5802 Diversity Monitor zum Einsatz.
Es muss mit Support gedruckt werden, die Fill Density war bei 35%
Der Antennenaufnahme-Dom muss etwas mit Schaumstoff gefüllt werden, damit der Halter nicht von der Senderantenne herunter rutsch. Alternativ lassen sich die Antennen Anschraubpunkte an der Rückseite der Antenne auf den Aufnahme-Dom übertragen, damit kann der Halter direkt mit dem Sender verschraubt werden.
Der Monitor selbst wird mittels einer Schraub-Mutter-Kombination befestigt und fixiert.
Neben dem Halter sind auch diese Teile zu drucken und bei den Schraubmuttern zusätzlich mit M5 Vierkantmuttern zu versehen. Die Schraubenaufnahme für die Führung im Empfänger wird mit 2 Senkkopfschrauben M5x10 bestückt.
Am Diversity Empfänger wird die Aufnahme der Schraubenaufnahme leicht gelöst und nach dem Einführen der Aufnahme wieder vorsichtig festgeschraubt. Damit werden die Senkkopfschrauben fixiert und drehen sich beim anschrauben des Monitors nicht mit.

title: Case for Raspberry Pi model B+ and 2 B

description.text:
This is yet another case for the Raspberry Pi model B+ and 2 model B. There are a number of these out there already, but none seemed to fit my purpose, so here we go. This design is made in OpenSCAD, so should be easy to modify as you see fit.

There are flags so you can optionally have a support shelf for the micro SD card, an opening for a camera module, openings for the LEDs and external access to the IO pins.

The case is made to snap together, but if you prefer, four countersunk screws can also be added. There is internal structure in the bottom, so you only have to remove a thin layer of plastic to expose the screw holes.

For a similar case for the original Raspberry, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:960801 For an overview of the various models, please see http://raspi.tv/2015/raspberry-pi-zero-updated-pi-family-photo
Should be a straight forward print in PLA or other material, with for instance 20% infill. If you have issues with warping, a brim support is recommended.

I keep losing my outdoor faucet handles. Although they are easy enough to buy, I never seem to be able to find one when I need one. A simple fix is to just print a bunch at once and leave them in the faucets.
There are quite a few faucet handles available for printing already, but I wanted one that was small, good looking and could be printed in PLA. The others mostly look like copies of commercially available keys. These requires printing in ABS, since they are to thin to take any force at all if you print them using PLA.

The common type of keys for outdoor faucets where I live (Sweden) seem to be called 8mm, but the square taps in the faucets are actually a bit smaller (7.5mm). I don´t know whats up with that, I just made the handle to fit my faucets.

You want the handle to be dense and snug since it should stay in place and be handle to handle a bit of force. I printed mine on 0.2 mm layer height and 75% infill. As usual you might have to adjust the scaling slightly to produce a snug fit. But the handle prints with perfect dimensions on my particular printer, which I have tried to calibrate as precisely as I can.

Inspired by that tower in Paris. Rectangular slot at the first base is
59.6 MM x 8.6 MM.

author: fahmiasm

title: Clamp On Cable Rack (w/ Snap Together Parts!)

description.text:
I wanted to make a cable rack even before krekr posted his design, but I wanted to make it clamp on to my workbench rather than be permanently attached.  This derivative takes his design and adds clamps so I don\'t have to drill holes into whatever old computer desk I happen to be using as workbench at the time!
I've wanted to make something that incorporates a custom clamp and I also have been wanting to try to make some snap together parts for a while, so I incorporated both into this design.  If you want to use something other than ABS to make these clamps though, it would be pretty easy to replace these snaps with T-slots for fasteners (which I might do anyway).

This project is cut from 1/4\" ABS. Many of the parts are mirrored so the textured side of the ABS sheet faces outward on all pieces when it's put together. Here are the settings used on my 35W Epilog to cut the parts (a little slow, but results in nice edges):
Speed: 3%
Power: 56%
Freq: 500 Hz Additionally, you\'ll need a square U-bolt (I used a 3/8\" 3-11/16x5\" U-Bolt) that is cut in half and 4 3/8\" 1-1/2\" washers. This cost me less than $5 total at my local hardware store. Construction should be pretty easy to follow from the pictures (please excuse the line that's out on the CCD of my camera!). Snap together the two outside faces of the camp with the two bridging pieces and glue (using ABS cement in this case) the contact surface of the clamp on top. I also glued together the two knob sections so they form a solid piece. After that, just insert the nut that came with your U-Bolt into the knob, sandwich this in between two washers, and insert it into the clamp body. Next, glue the two upper rack pieces together, making sure to pay attention to the side the small holes are on. Then just insert the clamps and you're done! Notes on snap together parts:
After a little experimentation, I found that 0.1" wide tongs with 0.05" overhangs (not accounting for what was taken off during the cutting of the parts) were still pretty stiff but bent enough to allow parts to be snapped together. These still require a bit of force to get to go together, and could use some tweaking. Also note that one of the knobs is a little smaller and not quite lined up right in the fully assembled picture. This was the first clamp I made and I made a few adjustments to this on the second clamp I built. The clamps turned out relatively bulky, but pretty functional.

title: Toyota Starlet GT (EP82) - Air Con Vent Directional Fins Support Bar

description.text:
My first Thingiverse contribution!

For the Toyota Starlet, air con vent directional fins often take much abuse. A rod/bar that keeps all the fins linked breaks quite easily, and causes the fins to then flop around.

Using Google Sketchup, I've designed tiny replacement bars to fix these on the Toyota Starlet GT (EP82), and I'm sure it can be adapted for other make/models if needed.

The center bar links up the 7 fins, while the side bar links up the 3 fins. I've also included a seat that can be added to the center vent to prevent it from wobbling around.

Let me know how it works!
Note, these are really small parts, so you may want to print them slow.

title: Velleman K8200 & 3DRag - Belt spanner for double Z-axis (Gesiima solution)

description.text:
This belt spanner is for the genereal set-up as you can see in this Thing:

I had changed to 20T XL Aluminium timing pulleys, so in consequence I had to adapt the spanning mechanism or take a shorter XL belt. I am using currently a 506XL037 and would have needed to go down to something like 490XL037.

For the pulley I am using a bearing and have provided it with shoulders to prevent the belt to slip off.

Why did I do the change - even with best calibration a printed 24T XL Timing pulley was not absolutely round and also if you print them separately there is a risk of different mean diametres. Both of these deficiencies lead to a variance in the layer height, which is visible.

I gather this to be an improvement on the following double Z-axis upgrade.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311980

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

ABS used at 260°C.
Designed with OpenSCAD. File is added to this release.

The single pulley belt spanner I printed with 30% infill. I made by design this Thing as stiff as possible, but I gather less than 30% infill will not do the trick.
For the pulley shoulder I took 25% infill and 1mm as wall, top and bottom thickness.

You will need some bearings. I used them with 10mm inner diametre, 22mm outer. (61900.ZZ)

A "surface map" guide to the solution is in the images (looking "outside-in"). For the record, it took my brother and his wife about 2 hours to get about halfway without the use of the surface map, and since they had to go I gave them the map and it took them another half hour to finish it. :D

NB: If you like my designs, please support my business by visiting my shapeways shop here: (www.shapeways.com/shops/mikelepage).

remixed_from.author: greyphilosophy
remixed_from.title: QU-BD OneUp/TwoUp Pulley for Gantry Counterweight

title: OneUp TwoUp Z Axis upgrade for a perfectly horizontal X axis

description.text: Using Some GT2 belt (or else), 3 pulleys and 2 gantry Belt holders, this upgrade ensure that your Z axis will keep your X axis perfectly leveled from bottom to top. You can even adjust it.

BOM first:

In addition to printed parts, you'd need:

  • 1 meter GT2 5mm belt (approximatly 600mm will be used)
  • 2 replacement m4 bolts at least 4mm longer than the originals
  • 3 20mm m4 bolts (you can add the nuts too but the parts holes are thight enough to do without)
  • 3 ball bearing (I used 624ZZ, the design allow for 1mm bigger/smaller...)
  • 6 15mm/3mm wood screws
  • 1 18mm/3mm wood screw (slightly longer is even better, I did not have one)

You'll also need to drill two big holes on the top and some small holes to help the wood screws to grip the wood where they are needed

The instructions

1) Remove the two top bolts, add the two top pulleys with the big holes pointing outward.
2) Secure them with the new, longer m4 bolts
3) Use the two big holes as a guide to drill same diameter (6mm) holes through the top.
4) Complete the two top pulleys parts with, for each, one bearing, 2 printed washers and one long m4 bolt
5) slide the belt through bot holes, ensuring the gripping side of the belt is turned up on the top of the printer
6) Attach the right extremity of the belt to the right holder, then, using the longest wood screw, fix the holder to the top right of the gantry, so that the pulley is perfectly aligned with the vertical rod.
7) Install the bottom pulley as on provided picture, ensure that from the side (left) view of the printer, it is centered to the vertical rod. Secure with 3 wood screws. Complete the pulley with the remaining bearing, two washers and the last long m4 bolt. Slide the belt under it (gripping side towards the bearing).
8) Secure the left holder on the side of the gantry with the last two remaing wood screws.
9) Move the hotend to the rightest position, and bring the gantry down by manualy actioning the Z coupler. Once the hotend will touch the bed, every extra turn you'll do to the coupler will bring the gantry closer to horizontal.
10)Try having the right side of the gantry approximatly hald a millimeter higher than the left.
11) Tension the belt and secure it to the right holder. A small flat screwdriver may help inserting the belt in the holder if necessary.
12) Using the coupler again, try to bring the gantry up. If everything went perfect, it will stabilize very close to horizontal.

Extra steps if necessary:

13) Check if the right part is too high or too low, repeat step 9 and adjust the belt accordingly in the right holder, 1 or 2 steps up or down. Repeat until leveling is reached. You may also try with a belt tensioner. or by adjusting the bed (not the best option).

description.text:
Update 24122017

Finally got around to uploading the files but word of warning i haven't tested any of the parts yet so please print at your own risk, you have been warned :-)

Raspberry Pi powered retro games emulator, running EmulationStaion.

The PiPlayer STL File is NOT for printing it is just a complete model of the unit.

The printable files will be made available once i have finished printing them and tried them out for size, i might need to make a few adjustments depending on the final prints.

This is my first 3d model as well as my first time doing 3d printing so your patience is appreciated :)

This project came about as i just finished building my printer 3 weeks ago and needed something to print, i had a Pi and was looking for ideas when i stumbled across the PiGrrl and Other designs from Adafruit as well as the Pi Boy Portable and Super Game PiSP.

After a lot of searching i decided there really wasn't any single design that covered all my needs ( and wants ) so decided to design my own.

So what is it i had in mind?

  • Most Importantly otherwise i couldn't do it, it had to fit on my printer. Only problem is it doesn't :) so the back and front are split into 3 pieces, left grip, right grip and center. This allows me to print on my printer that has a 225mm print bed, if your lucky enough to have a print bed 280mm or over they can be printed as on piece.

  • 5 inch HDMI screen ( able to use Pi Graphics Hardware acceleration ).
  • Raspberry Pi 2 as no other design seemed to use one yet.
  • Enough controls to cover any system.
  • The use of tactile switches.
  • large battery capacity 5400mAh lipo.
  • An easy to access and replace battery.
  • Soft on/off functionality
  • Minimal use of screws or at least hidden.
  • A comfortable design to hold while playing, only a few millimeters thicker than a classic wii controller..
  • Accessible USB ports and headphone socket.

New additions:

  • A system indicator and low battery indicator.
  • Modified supports for Pi and HDMI Display.
  • Grip and Body Interlocks to make assembly easier.

I will keep updating and add to this as i go along :)

To The Materials:

  • PowerBoost 500 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 500mA+
  • Raspberry Pi 2 Model B Desktop (Quad Core CPU 900 MHz, 1 GB RAM, Linux)
  • Kingston Technology 32 GB microSDHC Class 10 Flash Card with SD card adapter
  • Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier - MAX98306
  • 5 inch HDMI LCD 800×480 High Resolution for Raspberry Pi 2 Model B / Raspberry Pi Model B / B+ / A+
  • Teensy 2.0 USB AVR Development Board For Arduino ISP ATMEGA32U4
  • SODIAL(R) Classic Controller for Nintendo Wii
  • Edimax EW-7811UN 150Mbps Wireless Nano USB Adapter

All the above were purchased from Amazon UK mainly because im lazy theres one click checkout and it arrives next day :) Links for Amazon US below.

  • PowerBoost 500 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 500mA+
  • Raspberry Pi 2 Model B Desktop (Quad Core CPU 900 MHz, 1 GB RAM, Linux)
  • Kingston Technology 32 GB microSDHC Class 10 Flash Card with SD card adapter
  • Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier - MAX98306
  • 5 inch HDMI LCD 800×480 High Resolution for Raspberry Pi 2 Model B / Raspberry Pi Model B / B+ / A+
  • Teensy 2.0 USB AVR Development Board For Arduino ISP ATMEGA32U4
  • SODIAL(R) Classic Controller for Nintendo Wii
  • Edimax EW-7811UN 150Mbps Wireless Nano USB Adapter

Additional Items:

  • PowerBlock by petRockBlock
  • 3pcs Round 20mm 8ohm 0.5w Speaker

Printer:

Custom Ultimaker

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Printed in Rigid.ink ABS @240°C and 50mm/s.

comments.text:
What CAD program are you using? Would you be willing to share the model files directly?
Where did you get the CAD models for the R-Pi, Screen, analog joysticks, and other components (HDMI/DVI decoder, PowerBlock, speakers, etc)? (Apologies in advance if they're freely available on Thingiverse ... I'm just getting started here).
It's hard to tell; do you have CAD models of the various PCB's that will be required for your project to run? If so, and you've got all the packaging fleshed out this is beautiful! If not, I'm skeptical that it'll all fit ;-).
Have you done a circuit diagram yet? This is the most complex handheld game pi I've seen yet, and it doesn't use a Cupcade Adapter PCB for converting the joystick analog into digital for the Pi to use (which is good, b/c they've been out of stock seemingly forever, I don't see them becoming available any time soon). I don't see MCP3008 analog-to-digital converter listed in your parts list, how are you intending to connect the joysticks to the Pi?

Not your mother's extruder! Kidding... This simple yet very effective extruder is the brainchild of some members of the QR's community (in no particular order: Shauki B. / Mauro Manco (Exilaus) / Dale Dunn / Darkberg Aryavis (Flint Eastwood) and myself). I just tried to put it in a pleasant form. The name comes from the ring that looks like an aureola and it uses the flint wheel of a lighter. It was done initially for a NEMA17 and 1.75mm filament.

The nice detail about this design is that it's almost self-locking on the filament and the forces applied on the stepper motor are cancelled by each others.

This is an original design of an extruder that has the following features:

  • Symmetrical load on stepper axis;
  • Adjustable filament pressure without spring;
  • Simple & open design (easy to see what's happening inside);
  • No need for a geared reducer, direct drive;
  • Support flexible filament (anti-buckling support on both extrusion and retraction);
  • Best bang for your buck;

Bill of Material:

  • 1 flint from either mini bic or clipper lighter;
  • PTFE liner 40 cm for the loop + your regular bowden line;
  • 2 608 bearings;
  • 2 screws M3 20 mm length;
  • 3 M4 nuts to secure the PTFE line;
  • 1 stepper motor NEMA 1.7A (or even lower);
  • 4 shims / inner diameter >5 mm (I used rolls from a used bicycle chain;
  • 1 screw M3 5 mm length

See it in action:

  • https://youtu.be/F3HcuB7CWsA

Files for modification are publicly available and with a free Onshape account here:

  • https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5c209690b10748338481382a/w/6d6638f54420d7c76fe7949d/e/2d47f4694787414fab59244e

Successfully printed in PLA, ABS or PETG (2 shells and 20% infill is enough... But your milage may vary).

For details about fitting the coil on the stepper motor, you can find them by looking for #bicgear, #saintflint or #flintfeeder on Google Plus.

For fixing of the coil, the trickiest part of this build, having it only glued on the stepper shaft is not enough, it must be compressed axially, otherwise, it will "uncoil" and break on pushing or retracting the filament (depending on the direction of the filament vs the direction of the coil) and this will happen:

  • https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-EG7yNSY_t4g/VcNDeu_EsrI/AAAAAAAAVQM/EiHdUqD-O80/s426-p/IMG_20150806_121353.jpg

Some alternatives were available (Clipper lighter with solid flint wheel and internal 5 mm diameter), but more recent models have smaller holes and drilling this stuff is REALLY hard (You need to get a drill made for ceramic or glass as shown in one of the picture. Better to be good quality if you intend to make several, otherwise you can cheap but it probably won't last 1 or 2). To secure it, the best is to tap the axle with an M3 thread and use wasted bicycle chain rolls as spacers (ask them to your local bike shop, they should give them for free) and stack them.

Steps to tap the shaft of the stepper motor:

Imobilize the axle with the tool used to secure the thread maker (which means you may need another one);
Drill a hole 2.5 mm diameter 10 mm deep into the shaft;
Form the thread with a 3 steps M3 forming tool, since the hole is blind (not going through) this is required;
You can also put some strong Loctite or Super Glue to help secure the coil (watch out not to cover the curled part);
You should be good to go... Hope it helps. Like I said, not your mother's extruder! But it worth every cent...

2015-09-03 Due to popular demand, I've just uploaded an MK8 edition.

2015-09-08 Adding the following postscript GCODE in your slicer will ease the change of material (will retract enough filament making it easy to empty the Bowden by hand). In my case 16 mm seems a good length for the E3DV6:

G92 E0; zero the extruded length
G1 F250 E-16; Retract filament from barrel
G92 E0; zero the extruded length again

Note: Add the reverse action at the beginning of a print to pull the correct length before starting. If you interrupt a print, remember that you won't have an empty extruder...

2015-09-13 Added Casino Chip
Print (x4) and insert in the bearing place BEFORE putting the bearings and the axles in place. Center and glue to the external race of the bearing on each side. Help if the color has a good contrast with the body of the extruder.

2015-09-29 Corrected diameter of drilling for tapping the step motor
The corrected diameter before forming the thread is 2.5 mm. 2 mm is possible (I did it), but it's way easier to go with 2.5 mm. Thanks Shauki B. for the note.

2015-10-20 Added 3 mm version.

2015-11-09 After some experiment, I wouldn't recommend the 3 mm version for the following reasons:

  • Due to the layout and the compact size of the extruder, in order to fit, the path has to be curved (otherwise the M6 nuts won't fit). This is adding substantial friction.
  • The ratio of surface contact vs radius of the gear doesn't play in favor of the 3 mm version. Grinding is much likely to happen;
  • The 3 mm filament is much less flexible and more prone to break in the curves than the 1.75 mm;

For all the above reason, I think it's better to stick with Wade's or other derivatives that privilege a straight path... Sorry guy, I tried!
(Note: I still enthusiastically recommend it for 1.75 mm. It never let me down...)

01-10-2016 Added MK7 version.

comments.author: nomukaiki

comments.text: At first, it takes a little additional effort when PTFE line and nuts are not in place (that is, not properly aligned). Once done, this doesn't take more effort than to push the filament through  regular bowden tube. The "curve enforcer" can help if the extra PTFE line is a little short, but with 20 cm, it shouldn't be needed. Adding some silicon oil (other mention canola oil) in the PTFE does help to smooth out, but in general, the added benefit of the double traction overcomes largely the little added friction. Printing semi-flexible filament is perfectly possible and with great results:

This is a 3D print of an ellipse circle, its the first thing I made for my 3d printer (ultimaker 2 ext). It was designed with sketchup.
I printed the parts with PLA, sliced with Cura.
Hope you like it.

Trammel – ellipse circle

1) Print all parts. (Print the small parts two at once.)
2) Remove some burr with a knife or a fine sandpaper.
3) Put the splint with the knob together, you can hear a “klick”.
4) Give them into the runner and use a little bit of silicon spray. Test if they slide well.
5) Fix the hexagon female screws (M3) in the knobs with a drop of superglue.
6) Screw the screws (length 12mm, diameter 3mm) in the gears and in the pencil – holder.
7) Put four little wood screws in the holes of the runner. They are used as pins.
8) Assemble the pencil – holder and use a piece of pencil and fix it with the screw.
9) Test the circle and enjoy!

description.text:
I am currently Building the awesome "Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 and found the uppermost X bar of the bottom-construction could tilt -> that sounded cryptic -> The bar that holds the lower part of the Z-stage: Z-motor and the lower portion of the two 12mm rods.

The brackets are 18x18x18mm and are meant for M3 counter-sunk screws.

I have not assembled all of it yet, and the tilting might be a passing issue, when everything is done.. I decided to forego any issues and wanted to Mount corner brackets on all the bottom-upper-joints (hope that make sense, but see Photo).

I thought it would be easy to find some corner brackets, but it wasn't (they were too big or had other wrong Measurements for my project), so I just designed some myself.
I used the Measurements from motedis.de and made 2 different models. One with guides and one without. They Work exactly the same, but the one with guides are a bit harder to print, unless you have good cooling (I don't).

Do yourself a favor and print them solid. There is no real material gain by skimping and it is annoying to see your corner-brackets bend or the screws going through them.

I printed some in both 0.1mm layer height and some in 0.2. Works fine.

The model with guides must/should be placed as it is (pyramid like) to get all details, but it might cause some issues internally.. Play around with it.. maybe even use a tad of support.

author: NerdAlert3D

description.text:
I know this is crude, but since I cant find a fan shroud that will fit on the new Ubis 13 metal hotend. I modified the fan shroud on the hot end so the following design would fit
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356001

comments.text: Problem with this fan bracket.  The notch creates an escape path for the air from the Ubis 13 fan.  This results in not enough cooling to the lower part of the Ubis 13.  Result:  Filament will melt too high within the Ubis 13, sometimes (not always) causing the filament to eventually get jammed up within the Ubis 13.  This won't happen right away.  At first, everything will seem fine.  But after a few minutes of printing, you will probably see the problem.  There are variables such as extruder temperature, type of filament, etc.  Cleaning out a jammed Ubis 13 is not easy.  The real solution here would be to modify the shroud itself, instead of the bracket holding the Ubis 13 fan.  Note:  I waited a LONG time through much trial and error before posting this.  I could be wrong, but I am at least 90% sure
comments.author: sgreenwalt

comments.text:
Well I would have to disagree. I have over 100 hours of print time with this shroud and have had no problems. I've done short prints and super long prints.
The one thing that will cause this hot end to jam is moisture in the filament. Brook has documented this on the g+ boards.
So if your getting jams, try a different brand of filament, and also make sure the z set is correct.
comments.author: sgreenwalt

My daughter loves narwhals.  I promised to print her something on my ToM.  This was a conversion from a sketchup file by Aerilius on google 3d warehouse.  I scaled, split it in two.  Seems to print well.

title: Golden Ratio Calipers - Print in Place

description.text:
get a sneak peak on my latest works in progress on patreon


A simple device for checking the golden ratio. It has about 1.5 mm of play since the hinges are printed in one piece, but it is a fun to play around with and check proportions..

Orient the part so that the circular details of the hinges are facing up. Use support material for overhangs directly over the build plate. I found that a 30% fill for the support works good to keep the segments reasonably flat on the supported surface.

Once printed, remove support and work a blade in the part line around hinges until it can open and close.

description.text:
get a sneak peak on my latest works in progress on patreon


This was an old design school project of a toy for teaching children a dog's body language to reduce the risk of bite injuries. You can see the full project here.

I liked the design so I decided to make it 3d printable. It's arms, legs, neck and head can rotate giving it various postures. The print snaps together with no glue or fasteners.

Prints well with standard settings, except I upped the support material density to 30%. The head relies the most on support material, and it helps the part fit more cleanly.

Refer to the "gizmo_total.stl" for the orientations I used for all of the parts.

comments.text: Nice job. Just printed one for a friend's little girl. It came out perfect, but I have a few suggestions that made the print better. First, I split the top right down the middle and printed it in two pieces without support, then glued the two halves together with E6000. title: Hinge Style Fan Bracket for Makergear M2

description.text:
I have never been satisfied with the stock fan bracket system on the M2. It pulls on the wires when flipped out of the way, and using the only bolt holding it in place as the pivot point just feels like "bad engineering". I also never liked the fact that in order to flip the 50mm fan out of the way of seeing the print, you have to take the 40mm fan away from cooling the extruder. I have tried the numerous other designs that I have found here, and while many of them were beautiful designs, they either did not address these issues to my satisfaction, or they introduced new problems with the printing process.So, since I needed a project to do in order to learn AutoCAD, I decided to redesign this system. Here is my first AutoCAD design, and hopefully the first of many submitted "Things".

UPDATE: 1/26/17
I have updated the STL for this. It is slightly shorter so it better clears the bed clips. I also added a clip to the side that holds it in the up or down position.

https://tinkercad.com/things/hKcDOhFprKg-rampscase-14-revised
I was looking for a Ramps 1.4 case and came across this one, I liked the style of it. But since he had only made it for a CNC machine, I revamped it.
Added a mount for a 40mm fan, through holes for cables "layout may change" bigger vents on the front panel, access area for hotend/heatedbed/fan blocks and an access area up top to tighten and loosen the block screws.
I also re aligned the case rails so no more dremel is needed to get the back plate to fit correctly.
I have not printed this Item yet, as my printer is currently being upgraded and is out of commission please print at your own risk.
Feedback welcome.
UPDATE: 6/3/2013
Split up parts into individual .Stl files.
Revised the back panel, so it will now print flat.
Added a Main.stl with breakaway supports for the long bridges (for those printers like mine that have issues with long bridges), supports are .5mm thick and should easily break out with a little force.
***Fixed and re aligned rails for the front panel, (missed that they were off) now there should be no need for a dremel at all.

He is video of the robot walking. https://youtu.be/7MM_pvcmK4M He is a video that shows the process I have made so far. http://youtu.be/Fw_4WeCc6eE http://youtu.be/gWpZHsl3M4Q http://mike-ibioloid.blogspot.com/2013/09/robby-clone-20.html These are parts to the DARwIn-OP. Which is a open hardware and software research robot. CAD files are here: http://sourceforge.net/projects/darwinop/files/Hardware/Mechanics/Physical%20Information/ Robotis website:
http://www.robotis.com/xe/darwin_en http://www.flickr.com//photos/[email protected]/sets/72157627088031578/show/ http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/5623759896/ Videos of brackets being printed
http://mike-ibioloid.blogspot.com/2011/07/videos-of-darwin-op-brackets-being.html Check out page 62 of Robot Issue 38 January/February 2013. My article on this project is: DARwIn-OP Cloning 3D printingÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂa case studyÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ¬ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂby Michael Overstreet You can also check out Make Magazine volume #34, page 66 for more details on how I made the clone. http://blog.makezine.com/2013/04/26/cloning-the-darwin-op/ Video of all of the brackets printed out. http://youtu.be/qP0Hl94YmfE DARwIn-OP RoMeLa website:
http://www.romela.org/main/DARwIn_OP:_Open_Platform_Humanoid_Robot_for_Research_and_Education RoMeLa (Robotics & Mechanisms Lab),
Virginia Tech First videos of the robot in action. http://youtu.be/z-RA5v5_5i4 http://youtu.be/5VuZTewMSKY http://mike-ibioloid.blogspot.com/2013/04/robby-walking-tests-i-am-so-close.html

I should add that we are creating our STL files in AutoDesk 123D. I am starting to like this software more and more! http://www.123dapp.com/downloads Here is a link to my instructables guide on how I made the DARwIn-OP clone for more information. http://www.instructables.com/id/Robot-Cloning-by-DIY-3d-printers/

comments.text: i just finished my phd in neural computation specializing in developmental knowledge representation and sensorimotor grounded language acquisition, and continually through my phd i kept thinking of how my project would benefit from having access to "real" sensiromotor data from a small humanoid robot instead of the simulated data i was using (and, of course, you have to start this way -- but it's nice to make the transition at some point).  i was trying to price one of these out the other day, and really the $10k price tag seems like it's ALL servo.  what makes them $220 each?  is it the torque, or the digital interface with feedback?  could you take a much less expensive but similarly torque-speced servo, and add on some small boards of your own design to give them the same functionality for a quarter of the price?

description.text:
It is a mini size soap box which can take one standard size bath soap standing inside. It has following features:

  1. material saving: it is only 60mm35mm50mm. It saves more than 50% of material comparing to a normal soap box with soap lying down in it.
  2. easy to clean: bottom is detached, and you can reach every corner of it easily.
  3. easy to print: same as my other design, no support required.
  4. save your soap: small contact surface with mesh bottom, and special water drain, minimize the soap dissolve by water. I put them on shelf in shower, lol, my soap doesn't shrink. Of course if you like a cap, It is also easy to add one for it.
    The only problem is that sometimes soap might stuck to bottom mesh, just move the soap back and forth once, then it comes out with no issue.

comments.text: Worked great for the basic ivory bar soap in USA. Thanks for the awesome design and idea!
comments.author: wizechatmgr

comments.text: Glad to know you like it. Actually I designed it for my Ivory bar soap too :D
